Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Story: I glanced at the calendar on my phone, the bright red circle around Saturday glaring at me—a reminder of the family gathering my daughter had planned weeks ago. My grandson had called me yesterday, his voice bubbling with excitement about showing me his new train set. I promised him I’d be there, and I could already picture his hopeful eyes searching for me in the crowd. But as I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, my phone buzzed again. The contractor’s message was urgent: a delivery delay threatened to push our project off schedule, and he needed me on-site that same Saturday to coordinate a solution. My mind raced with the weight of both worlds—my family expecting my presence, my team relying on my leadership. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me from both sides, as I tried to imagine disappointing either my grandson or my colleagues. The pressure built in my chest, and I stared at the calendar, paralyzed, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
